Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC: On Compact, High-Performance Cooling Technologies Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
PROGRAM DIRECTOR'S RECOMMENDATION

IIP 1238318
Purdue University
Garimella

This proposal seeks funding for a third five-year term (Phase III) of the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center at Purdue University, the Cooling Technologies Research Center, which started operations in 2002. The Center addresses research and development needs of industries in the area of high-performance heat removal from compact spaces.

The uniqueness of the proposed Center draws from its strong focus on heat transfer technologies and related thermal management issues. The research approach relies heavily on experimental investigations, backed by theoretical and numerical analysis. The Center draws participants from the Schools of Mechanical Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Materials Science and Engineering, Physics and Chemistry at Purdue University, who contribute complimentary competencies in heat transfer, micrrofluidics, microfabrication, nanotechnology, refrigeration, computational techniques, mechantronics, controls, acoustics, and diagnostics and measurements. The Center continues to pursue a research agenda that is of immediate relevance to its industry members, while focusing on the fundamental challenges in each technology. The Center has come to be recognized globally for its leadership in this area, and was awarded the 2011 Alexander Schwarzkopf Award for Technological Innovation.

Based on the outcomes the center has realized during its first 10 years of operation, Phase III renewal of the CTRC will continue to produce research outcomes that support the needs of industry sectors designing and using high performance electronics. The Center's strong multi-disciplinary culture promotes broad impacts on education and diversity. Exposure to the Center ecosystem ensures that tomorrows research leaders understand the team-based, problem solving skills needed for successful cross-disciplinary research. The Center is committed to continually and proactively recruiting, nurturing and mentoring women and under-represented groups, at the graduate and undergraduate levels, during their pursuit of academic excellence. The Center benefits from, and adds to, the multiple, strong diversity and outreach programs housed at Purdue University.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Cooling Technologies Research Center (CTRC) addresses research and development needs of companies and organizations in the area of high-performance heat removal from compact spaces, and has attracted a large number of leading multinational companies and organizations as members. The Center has come to be recognized globally for its leadership in this area, and was honored with the 2011 Alexander Schwarzkopf Award for Technological Innovation. Current and previous member companies include Aavid Thermalloy, Air Force Research Labs (WPAFB), Alcatel-Lucent (Bell Labs), Alcoa, Apple, Boeing, Cisco Systems, Delphi Electronics & Safety, Denso, DuPont, Eaton, Ford, General Electric, Graftech, HTRI, Honeywell, Huawei Technologies, IBM, Intel, John Deere, Johnson Matthey Electronics, LG Electronics, Laird Technologies, Malico, Midea Holding Group, Modine Manufacturing, MuRata, Nanoconduction, Nokia, Northrop Grumman, Parker Hannifin, Philips, Qualcomm, Raytheon, Rockwell Automation, Rockwell Collins, Rogers Corp, Samsung Electronics, Sandia National Labs, Schlumberger, Sharp Laboratories, Sony Computer Entertainment, Sony Corp, Sterling PCU, Sun Microsystems, Tenneco, Texas Instruments, Toyota Motor Company, and Wolverine Tube.

Virtually all product sectors in the electronics industry face critical cooling challenges. In a variety of cooling applications such as power electronics, cellular base stations and mobile phones, automotive electronics, portable/wearable electronics, electric vehicle batteries, power distribution systems in computers, transformers, military electronics and avionics, there is a need to efficiently remove heat from compact spaces. The space and performance constraints imposed call for high-performance cooling techniques, which involve innovative approaches to the application of existing methods as well as novel cooling concepts. The Center has brought together a team of over 15 total faculty members from mechanical engineering, electrical and computer engineering, materials engineering, and physics disciplines to address these needs.  Collectively, this group has leading experts in the fields of heat transfer, microfluidics, computations, refrigeration, microfabrication, nanoscale heat transfer, mechatronics, controls, acoustics, sensing and actuation, diagnostics and measurements.

Through their long-time participation in the Center, member companies have indicated their recognition of the value and uniqueness of the work performed. The successes developed over the course of the years of Center operation are backed by numerous examples of successful industry-university collaborations within the I/UCRC framework and the over 500 journal and conference papers that have been published based on CTRC work.  Most examples of technology transfer result from leveraged state, federal, and industry funded applied research that emerges from pre-competitive Center projects. A widely recognized example is the series of projects carried out by CTRC researchers in collaboration with Center member Delphi Electronics & Safety. Over the course of 2004-2009, leveraged funding from the Indiana 21st Century Research & Technology Fund supported numerous studies on the direct cooling of silicon chips using microchannel heat sinks with dielectric fluids to prevent overheating of devices used in hybrid and electric vehicles. From 2008-2011, a group of CTRC faculty was awarded a Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) Thermal Ground Plane (TGP) grant in partnership with member Raytheon Company to develop high-performance heat spreaders. Most recently, from 2013-16, another DARPA grant was award to researches in the CTRC in collaboration with Raytheon, IBM, and Delphi to investigate direct integration of fluidic cooling channels in electronic devices. Individual projects have been carried out under separate agreements, stemming from precompetitive projects, with multiple members (Apple, Boeing, Delphi, Eaton, Huawei, Intel, Samsung, Sony, and Toyota) as a result of their positive experience with the Center.

Preparing current and future scientists and engineers for innovative advancements in diverse fields and industries is critical. There have been over 54 PhD and 31 Master’s students graduated from the CTRC, 55 of whom have had internship or full-time employment with member companies (with 22 of the students or visiting researchers being in faculty positions at prestigious universities around the world). All doctoral students graduating from the CTRC have participated in at least one industrial internship. The Center’s strong multidisciplinary culture promotes broad impacts on education and diversity. Exposure to the Center ecosystem ensures that tomorrow’s research leaders understand the team-based, problem-solving skills needed for successful cross-disciplinary research. The Center has been committed to continually and proactively recruiting, nurturing, and mentoring women and under-represented groups, at the graduate and undergraduate levels.


Last Modified: 06/13/2017
Modified by: Suresh V Garimella
